Expectation1: Follow traffic laws and drive defensively
Situation1: A school zone with children near the curb appears just as a construction detour narrows the lanes
Expectation2: Arrive on time for scheduled volunteer shifts
Situation2: They are the only volunteer assigned to unlock the facility and begin the service for people already waiting outside.
Story:
I glanced at the clock on my dashboard—7:55 a.m. My volunteer shift started at 8:00 sharp, and I was the only one with the keys to open the community center. I pictured the line of people already waiting outside, some of them elderly, some with children, all depending on me to let them in and start the morning service. My phone buzzed with a reminder: “Don’t be late!” I pressed the gas a little harder, hoping to make up for lost time. 

Suddenly, I hit a construction detour. Orange cones funneled traffic into a single lane, right as I approached a school zone. Children clustered near the curb, some darting unpredictably. The speed limit dropped, and a crossing guard raised a hand, signaling me to slow down. My heart pounded. If I followed the rules and drove carefully, I’d be late, letting down everyone at the center. But if I rushed, I’d be risking the safety of these kids and breaking the law. The weight of both roles pressed on me, each demanding something I couldn’t give to the other. I gripped the wheel, torn between duty and responsibility, unsure which expectation I could afford to disappoint.
